title: Establishes public policy that no antenuptial agreement shall become binding for 30 days during which period either party thereto may withdraw upon notice to other
summary: Establishes a public policy that no antenuptial agreement shall become binding for 30 days during which period either party thereto may unilaterally withdraw therefrom upon written notice served personally upon the other person; also requires that such agreements be in writing, subscribed by the parties, and acknowledged or proven in the manner required to entitle a deed to be recorded, and contain the addresses of the parties at which notice of withdrawal may be served.

BILL NUMBER:S2269

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the general obligations law and the domestic relations law,
in relation to establishing the public policy of the state that no
antenuptial agreement become
binding for thirty days during which period either party may
withdraw upon written notice to the other and requiring such
agreements to be in writing and acknowledged

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
The purpose of this
bill is to avoid
the circumstance wherein one party to an antenuptial agreement is
pressured to sign such agreement, often at the last minute, often on
the eve of the wedding, thereby placing said party in a significantly
inferior position relative to the agreement.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
Amends the General
Obligations Law
§3-303 and adds the particulars that are required for an antenuptial
agreement to be binding. Those conditions include the retirement, in
§3-303 (4), that there is a thirty day period during which no
antenuptial agreement shall be binding, valid or enforceable. During
this thirty day period, the agreement is incipient and executory
only, and either party to the agreement may unilaterally withdraw
from the agreement by written notice to the other party. Antenuptial
agreements must also contain a notice of the rights granted by these
new provisions and of the requirements for an agreement to be valid
and binding. The Domestic Relations Law is also amended, Section 236,
Subdivision 3 of Part B so, as to include a reference to General
Obligations Law §3-303, which specifically covers the above mentioned
requirements for an antenuptial agreement to be valid.

JUSTIFICATION:
As spelled out in the legislative findings and
declaration of intent, important rights are often surrendered when
one party is placed in the position that, if she or he refuses to
sign an antenuptial agreement, the wedding may be canceled. Often
these agreements are presented on the eve of matrimony, and with
out-of-town guests having arrived and other extreme pressures
present, she or he may be in no position to enter into negotiations
for a more palatable and fair agreement. The thirty day period in
which either party may unilaterally revoke the agreement places the
parties on a more even footing, and the pressure of signing such an
agreement at the last minute is removed.
This thirty day period may force would be spouses to present any
proposed agreement well before the marriage, thus assuring fairness -

or letting the party presented with the agreement see what her or his
intended spouse is really all about.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None to New York State

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Ninety days after it shall have become a law and it
shall only apply prospectively to agreements executed on or after the
effective date of this act.
